questions.uddipok: Write a letter to your brother describing the importance of reading newspaper.

sub_questions.explanation:
Feni
04.07.2024
Dear Mijanur,
Hey! How are things going at college? I'm writing to you today because I wanted to talk about something important – reading newspapers.
I know you might not be a big fan of sitting down with a physical paper these days, but trust me, there are a lot of benefits to be had from this "old-fashioned" habit.
Firstly, newspapers keep you informed. They give you a well-rounded view of current events, both locally and internationally. It's important to stay up-to-date on what's happening in the world, not just through social media, which can be filled with rumors and biased opinions. Newspapers offer a more reliable source of information.
Secondly, reading newspapers improves your vocabulary and communication skills. They're full of rich, descriptive language, and you'll be exposed to new words and writing styles. This can definitely help you improve your own writing and speaking abilities.
Thirdly, newspapers challenge your mind and keep it sharp. Reading articles on various topics, from politics and science to sports and entertainment, engages your brain in a different way. It's a good mental exercise and helps you stay mentally stimulated.
Finally, newspapers can even introduce you to new interests. You might stumble upon an article about something you never knew existed, sparking a new passion or hobby.
I know you're busy with classes and other activities, but even just skimming through the headlines or reading a few articles a day can make a big difference. Maybe there's a section you'd find particularly interesting, like sports or technology? You could even consider subscribing to a digital version of a newspaper for easier access.
Give it a try, [Brother's Name]! I think you might be surprised at how much you learn and enjoy it.
Let me know what you think if you decide to check it out.
Best,
Harun

questions.uddipok: Following is a bar diagram containing data on internet users of Bangladesh from 2014 to 2019. The numbers are in millions. Analyze the graph.

sub_questions.explanation: The bar graph illustrates the steady increase in the number of internet users in Bangladesh from 2014 to 2019. The graph shows that in 2014, there were around 40 million users, which increased to approximately 60 million by 2015. Then, the number of users suddenly decreased and reached 50 million in 2016. Only this particular year marks a decrease in the number of users. Then, a significant surge occurred in 2017 and the number of internet users jumped to 70 million. This marks an increase highlighting a rapid growth in internet accessibility and usage. The number of users remained same in 2018. Finally, in 2019, the number of internet users took another jump and turned into 80 million in total. Analysing the graph, we find that within five years, the number of internet users in Bangladesh increased significantly, making it double. It is a clear indication that during this period, the country's digital infrastructure improved significantly. It also shows that people of Bangladesh are. getting accustomed to the modern technologies.

questions.uddipok:
Complete the following story in your own words.
Once there lived a wolf in a wood. He killed a lamb and started to eat it. But suddenly, a bone stuck in his throat. This gave him pain and he went about not knowing what to do ……………………………..

sub_questions.explanation:
Completing a story
The Wolf and the Crane
Once there lived a wolf in a wood. He killed a lamb and started to eat it. But suddenly, a bone stuck in his throat. This gave him pain and he went about not knowing what to do. Then the wolf saw a crane by the side of a stream. The crane was looking for fish. "Good morning, Mr Crane," said the wolf. "You might be looking for fish, I will give you a good reward (পুরস্কার) if you do me a favour." The crane asked the wolf what favour he wanted. Then the wolf said that a bone had stuck in his throat and he wanted the crane to bring out that bone with the help of his long beak (ঠোট). The crane was by nature excessively (অতিশয়) greedy. Moreover, he thought it to be a very easy work and agreed to the proposal. He asked the wolf to open wide his mouth and brought out the bone with his long beak. Then the crane (সারস পাখি) demanded the reward. The wolf (নেকড়ে) said, "Reward! You put your head into my throat and I did not crush (পিষা/ভাঙ্গা) the same into pieces. Is it not a reward?" Being afraid, the crane at once flew away to a tree. Sitting on the branch of the tree he said, "You are an ungrateful (অকৃতজ্ঞ) fellow and God will punish you for this."

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
(a) What does WHO say about adolescence?
(b) How many adolescents are boys and how many are girls in Bangladesh?
(c) How is the condition of the adolescent girls in Bangladesh?
(d) What is the legal age of marriage for boys and girls in our country?
(e) When do the boys become ready for marriage?

sub_questions.explanation:
(a)
The World Health Organization (WHO) defines adolescence as the period of life between 10 and 19 years of age. This stage marks the transition from childhood to adulthood, characterized by significant physical, emotional, and social development. Adolescents experience rapid growth and undergo various changes that influence their health, behavior, and interactions with society.
(b)
According to the 2022 Bangladesh Census, the population of adolescents aged 10–14 is approximately 16.6 million, with 8.5 million boys and 7.8 million girls. For the 15–19 age group, there are about 16.5 million adolescents, comprising 8.1 million boys and 8.5 million girls. In total, adolescents make up about 28.8% of Bangladesh's population, with a near-equal distribution between boys and girls.
(c)
Adolescent girls in Bangladesh face several challenges
Child Marriage : Approximately 51% of girls in Bangladesh are married before the age of 18, making it one of the highest rates globally.
Education : While enrollment rates for girls have improved, many still face barriers to completing secondary education, especially in rural areas.
Health Risks : Early pregnancies pose significant health risks, with many adolescent girls becoming mothers before reaching adulthood.
Violence and Abuse : A significant number of adolescent girls experience physical or sexual violence, often within intimate relationships.
These issues hinder their development and access to opportunities, perpetuating cycles of poverty and inequality.
(d)
In Bangladesh, the legal age for marriage is 18 for girls and 21 for boys, as stipulated by the Child Marriage Restraint Act of 2017. However, the law includes provisions that allow for exceptions under certain circumstances, such as parental consent and court approval, which have been criticized for potentially undermining efforts to prevent child marriage.
(e)
While the legal age for marriage is 21 for boys in Bangladesh, readiness for marriage is influenced by various factors beyond age, including emotional maturity, financial stability, and societal expectations. Cultural norms often dictate that men should be established in their careers and capable of supporting a family before marriage. However, these expectations can vary widely across different communities and regions within the country.

questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text.
When you are in the driving seat of a car, you have the steering and the horn in your hands, the brake and accelerator under your feet, eyes open looking ahead, left and right. The same can be said about a motorcycle rider, with some modifications. These are all very visible. But, behind all, there is something that keeps working unseen. And that is the Central Processing Unit (CPU), your brain. CPUS are artificially intelligent machines that are programmed to do specific jobs under fixed conditions and judgements. But the human brain is intelligent by nature. It is the most sophisticated machine that is able to operate on ever-changing conditions and standards of judgement. As conditions in the traffic keep invariably changing, this virtue of sophistication of your brain must be at work when you are driving. The difference between traffic in the roads and highways and racing circuit must not be blurring inside you. Never imagine yourself to be a Michael Schumacher driving an F − 1 \mathrm{F}-1 F − 1 at 300 m p h 300 \mathrm{mph} 300 mph . Leave no room for fantasy. You must always be ready to encounter unexpected behavior from any vehicle or pedestrian. 'Keep your cool' is easy to advice but difficult to maintain. Still you must always restrain yourself because, at the end of the day, you don't want to be regarded as a killer. Now you see, the last thing that differentiates you from a computer is your conscience.

sub_questions.explanation:
Summary
There are some works like driving a car or a motorcycle, which are visible. But there is something that keeps working unseen and that is the Central Processing Unit (CPU), our brain. Our brain, which is intelligent by nature, works behind the screen while CPUs are artificially intelligent. It is the most sophisticated machine operating on ever-changing conditions and standards, of judgement. Conditions in the traffic keep invariably changing and our brain must work at the time of our driving. We should be realistic and as such should not rely on imagination. And we should always remain careful about unexpected behaviour from others on the road. Still we must restrain ourselves as we do not want to be regarded as a killer. Here is the difference between a computer and us. And our conscience makes the difference.
